title: What tragic Tara Palmer-Tomkinson told pal just weeks before she died after brave battle with drug demons
text:
'every day I want drugs more' What tragic Tara Palmer-Tomkinson told pal just weeks before she died after brave battle with drug demons 
The 45-year-old socialite, found dead on Wednesday, ­fought addiction for years Exclusive By DAN WOOTTON, BIZARRE EDITOR 9th February 2017, 10:26 pm Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments TARA Palmer-Tomkinson broke down in tears weeks before her death, telling a close pal: “Every day I want drugs.” 
The 45-year-old socialite , found dead on Wednesday, ­battled addiction for years. Getty Images The 45-year-old socialite was found dead on Wednesday 
Pals privately feared she had relapsed and slipped into a “very dark place”. 
The Sun told how Tara, who mixed with the Royal Family , was found at her London flat five days after builders heard a loud crash. 
Cops called her death “un­explained” and were keeping an open mind over the cause. PA:Press Association Pals privately feared she had relapsed and slipped into a ‘very dark place’ News Group Newspapers Ltd 15 She was discovered at her London flat five days after builders heard a loud crash 
She spoke of her desperate drugs battle just weeks ago, confessing: “I’m do­ing everything I can to stay clean, but therapy isn’t enough any more.” 
The sobbing socialite made the heart-rending admission to a pal after years fighting addiction. 
Tara’s close friend said: “It was a very emotional conversation and would end up being the last time we spoke. 
“Tara was crying when we first started talking and I asked what was wrong. She said that she felt down and lonely. Goff Photos The last picture of Tara was taken outside her home on January 25 this year Splash News Cops called her death ‘un­explained’ and were keeping an open mind over the cause Getty Images 15 The former It Girl had a non-malignant brain tumour and, according to pals, developed severe agoraphobia 
“That’s when she said, ‘Every day I want drugs. I’m doing everything I can to stay clean but therapy isn’t enough’. 
“I remember those words clearly as there was a sense of desperation. She didn’t want to give in, but it was obvious how difficult things had been. 
“Yet she said she was going to try different therapies and was going to ‘Rise like a phoenix’. She still had hope.” 
The former It Girl — known as TPT — had a non-malignant brain tumour and, according to pals, had also developed severe agoraphobia . 
She chose to leave her home only briefly apart from a Thai holiday last month, when the region was rocked by flooding. PA:Press Association Tara arrives at Wills and Kate’s wedding at Westminster Abbey Rex Features Tara skiing with a young Prince Harry in 1997 Getty Images Tara’s best friend Duncan James tweeted he was ‘heartbroken’ Holly Willoughby shares touching memories of Tara Palmer-Tomkinson The pal explained: “Tara said she wanted to beat her agoraphobia and go out more.
“She also said she wanted to re-launch her career and that this year felt she’d find a man. We laughed about a lot of the men she’d dated and how weird one of her final ex-lovers was.” 
It was clear she was back staying up late and drinking again 
We told how friends feared Tara, who had connections to the royals and attended Prince William’s 2011 wedding, may have relapsed into addiction at a pre-Christmas party. 
Today we can reveal those close to her made numerous attempts at an intervention. RELATED STORIES 'SHE HAD THE BIGGEST HEART' Duncan James pays tribute to ex-girlfriend and best friend Tara Palmer-Tomkinson NINETIES IT Girl Following the sad news of her death we look back at Tara's life and why she never had kids TRAGIC LOSS A look back at the life of It Girl Tara Palmer-Tomkinson after her tragic death at 45 TARA'S FINAL DAYS TPT's body was 'discovered by cleaner' five days after loud bang heard inside her flat A REAL GEM Holly Willoughby recalls how kind pal Tara Palmer-Tomkinson gave her a Chanel diamond ring the first time they met 'an extraordinary person' Tara Palmer-Tomkinson said winning Fame Academy was the 'best night' of her life 
One said: “We had been asking her to seek extra help for a while now, especially when it was clear she was back staying up late and drinking again.” 
Tara, once a regular at Kensington’s Bottlery boozer, had been in reflective mood, acc­or­ding to the pal who had known her through the London showbiz circuit for over a decade. 
The friend said: “She said she wanted to see me this year as she hadn’t been going out. She said she’d been let down by a lot of people and was reflecting as it was the end of the year.” Getty Images Tara shares a tender moment with Prince Charles at a breast cancer awareness event at Clarence House in 2003 Rex Features The popular IT came second to Tony Blackburn on the first-ever series of I'm A Celebrity... in 2002 Rex Features She mingled with a range of celebs including Graham Norton Rex Features Pictured with a young Duchess of Cambridge in 2007 
Yet Tara still attempted to maintain a positive outlook. 
The friend said: “We laughed about a time she got locked out of her house in her G-string. 
“At a party a few years back she had lots of ping pong balls in her Chanel bag and was showing them to people. She was a true English eccentric.” 
But another friend said TPT effectively became a recluse af­ter her last rehab stint in 2012. Getty Images The 45-year-old had weekly visits to a therapist during the last 10 years of her life Splash News One friend said TPT effectively became a recluse af­ter her last rehab stint in 2012 
The pal said: “Her friends were all settled down with children and have busy lives. 
“Tara struggled to find her purpose in life and all the therapy only made her question her lifestyle of the past more. 
“She had very few people she could rely on as friends near the end. If she went out to events it was often on her own. 
“She lived in onesies and often looked bedraggled. Tara Palmer-Tomkinson’s touching tribute to ex partner Duncan James 
“One of the symptoms following drug rehab is that you often get far edgier than usual. 
“If you forget to take your medications or mix them up they can make you very confused and cause panic at­tacks. 
“It was a truly sad situation for anyone who knew her.” 
Ivan Massow, ex-chairman of the Institute of Contemporary Arts, “hit it off” with Tara after they shared a car to an event. 
Asked if she was in a “dark place”, he said: “Well, I know that every time I didn’t hear from her, that’s where she was.”
